meaning: The word 'because' is a conjunction used to introduce the reason or cause for something. It connects two clauses, explaining why something happened or why someone did something.
etymology: The word 'because' originates from the Middle English phrase 'by cause,' which was derived from the Old French 'par cause.' It combines 'by' (indicating the means) and 'cause' (reason). Over time, it evolved into the single word 'because.'
sentence: I stayed home because it was raining.
She succeeded because she worked hard.
Famous quote: 'I think, therefore I am.' — René Descartes (often paraphrased as 'I am because I think.')
short_stories: A child once asked their parent, 'Why is the sky blue?' The parent replied, 'Because the sunlight scatters in the atmosphere, and blue light scatters more than other colors.' The child smiled, satisfied with the explanation.
A man once said, 'I failed because I didn’t try hard enough.' His friend replied, 'No, you failed because you didn’t believe in yourself.'
poetry: Excerpt from 'Because I could not stop for Death' by Emily Dickinson: 'Because I could not stop for Death – / He kindly stopped for me – / The Carriage held but just Ourselves – / And Immortality.'

Excerpt from 'Because You Asked About the Line Between Prose and Poetry' by Howard Nemerov: 'Because you asked about the line between / prose and poetry, I will tell you / it is the difference between / the way a man walks and the way a bird flies.'
